questions.question: In an urban PHC, an increasing number of skin diseases are being reported due to inadequatewater supply in the region. What would be the adequate supply of water for them to meettheir needs for all domestic purposes?
questions.explanation: The given scenario of skin diseases is suggestive of water-washed diseases caused by improperhygiene related to an inadequate water supply. In urban areas, 150-200 litres per capita per day isthe recommended allowance to meet the needs for all kinds of domestic purposes.In rural areas, the set target of water supply to be achieved in India is around 50-55 litres percapita per day.
questions.chapter_heading: Water - I: Sources and purification of water

questions.question: What are the norms for the required litres of water per capita per day in rural areas?
questions.explanation: According to the National Rural Drinking Water Programme, the requirement of water in ruralareas (areas with public water posts) is 55 litres per capita per day. This is in accordance with the12th Five Year Plan.For reasons of comparability, the source of water provision in rural areas should be within adistance of 100 metres from the household or the time taken to fetch water should not be > 30minutes.Note: Park textbook mentions 40-50 litres per capita per day as the norm. However, in the 12thfive year plan period, the Government of India enhanced the rural drinking water supply normsfrom 40 litres to 55 litres per capita per day.

questions.explanation: 537Rain water is the purest form of water in nature. It contains a very low amount of total dissolvedsolids (TDS). questions.question: What is the area from which water drains into impounding reservoirs known as?
questions.explanation: The area draining into the impounding reservoirs are known as catchment areas.Impounding reservoirs are also called embankment ponds. These reservoirs are artificial lake-likewater bodies. They are made by building an embankment or earth fill in an area into whichnatural water flows and can be stored for usage. Dams are also built to create these reservoirs.Water from these reservoirs is second in purity to rainwater but is not completely free fromimpurities. questions.question: An outbreak of guinea worm disease was reported among villagers who used step wells fordrinking water. In order to arrest the spread of disease, a decision was made to replace stepwells with sanitary and safe wells. All of the following measures would be considered duringits construction except:

options.A: Must be located at least 15 metres away from sources of contamination
options.B: A partition space for washing clothes and vessels
options.C: Lining must be made to a depth of 6 metres or more
options.D: Hand-pump must be made to handle rough use

questions.explanation: Washing clothes, vessels, and bathing must be prohibited around wells to avoid contamination ofthe water.Step wells are a type of pucca wells which enable people to descend into the well to fetch water. Itis obsolete now, as there is considerable personal contact between the user and the water whichcan pose a health hazard to the community.539

questions.question: What is the minimum length that the platform of a well should extend around it in alldirections?
questions.explanation: The platform of a sanitary well should stretch for at least 1 metre around the well in all directions.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a water-washed disease?
questions.explanation: Cholera is a water-borne disease and not a water-washed disease. The diseases which are transmitted by improper hygiene and are widely related to circumstances where there is inadequate water supply are called water-washed diseases. Some examples of water-washed diseases are: Conjunctivitis, Trachoma, Scabies, and Typhus.
questions.chapter_heading: Water - I: Sources and purification of water

questions.question: A multipurpose worker is spraying herbicides on aquatic plants as part of vector controlmeasures in your area. Which of the following water-related diseases can be controlled by thisapproach?
questions.explanation: Filariasis (caused by B.malayi) is transmitted by Mansonia species of mosquito that breeds inwater bodies containing aquatic vegetation. It can be controlled by the use of herbicides to destroyaquatic vegetation.Water-related diseases are classified as:CategoryWater-borne diseasesWater-washed diseasesWater-based diseasesExamplesCaused by ingestion of watercontaminated by human or animal faeces, or urine containing pathogenic bacteria or viruses.ex: Cholera, typhoid, amoebic and bacillary dysentery, and other diarrhoeal diseases.Caused by poor personal hygiene.ex: Scabies, trachoma, flea-, lice- and tick-borne diseases, in addition to the majority of waterborne diseases (which are also water-washed).Caused by parasites found inintermediate organisms living in water.ex: Dracunculiasis,schistosomiasis and some other helminths.540CategoryWater-related diseases transmitted by insect vectorsExamplesCaused by vectors that breedin waterex: Dengue, filariasis,malaria, onchocerciasis, trypanosomiasis and yellow fever.

questions.question: 532When river water is stored properly, by how much percent does the bacterial count drop inthe first 5-7 days?
questions.explanation: When river water is stored properly, the bacterial count drops by as much as 90% in the first 5-7days.Purification during the storage of water is a natural process that takes place by physical, chemicaland biological phenomena. Components of water purification include storage, filtration anddisinfection.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a ceramic filter that can be used for small scale purification ofwater?
questions.explanation: Filtration of water on a small scale is done by ceramic filters like Pasteur Chamberland, Berkefeld,and Katadyn filters.Ceramic filters are not widely used in India. The most important parts of these filters are the filtercandles. Filter candles of the fine type help in removing bacteria but not viruses. These filtercandles need to be cleaned periodically as they get clogged with impurities and bacteria.Types of ceramic filters include:• Pasteur Chamberland filter - It has a candle made of porcelain.Image of a Pasteur Chamberland filter is shown below:5430• Berkefeld filter - it has a candle made of infusorial earth or kieselguhr.Image of a Berkefeld filter is shown below:DasBerkefeld-FilterBerkefeld FilterGesellschaft GmbHCELLE•-Katadyn filter the surface of this filter is coated with a silver catalyst. The incoming bacteria arekilled on contact with the surface by the oligodynamic action of silver ions which are liberated intothe water.Image of a Katadyn filter is shown below:544
